quotations.text: I have a house and a car.
Look what I have here — a frog I found on the street!
I have two sisters.
I have a lot of work to do.

definitions.text: To be related in some way to (with the object identifying the relationship).

quotations.text: I have breakfast at six o'clock.
Can I have a look at that?
I'm going to have some pizza and a beer right now.

definitions.text: To partake of a particular substance (especially a food or drink) or action.

quotations.text: I have already eaten today.
I had already eaten.

definitions.text: (auxiliary verb, taking a past participle) Used in forming the perfect aspect and the past perfect aspect.

quotations.text: I have to go.
Note: there is a separate entry for have to.
The couple always wanted to have children.
My wife is having the baby right now!
My mother had me when she was 25.
He's always bragging about how many women he's had.

definitions.text: To engage in sexual intercourse with.

quotations.text: Despite my protestations of love, she would not have me.

definitions.text: To accept as a romantic partner.

quotations.text: His English is still in its beginning stages, like my Creole, but he was able to translate some Creole songs that he's written into English—not the best English, but English nonetheless. He had me correct the translations. That kind of thing is very interesting to me. When I was learning Spanish, I would often take my favorite songs and try to translate them.
They had me feed their dog while they were out of town.

definitions.text: (transitive with bare infinitive) To cause to, by a command, request or invitation.

quotations.text: He had him arrested for trespassing.
The lecture's ending had the entire audience in tears.

definitions.text: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To cause to be.

quotations.text: The hospital had several patients contract pneumonia last week.
I've had three people today tell me my hair looks nice.

definitions.text: (transitive with bare infinitive) To be affected by an occurrence. (Used in supplying a topic that is not a verb argument.)

quotations.text: Their stories differed; he said he'd been at work when the incident occurred, but her statement had him at home that entire evening.
Anton Rogan, 8, was one of the runners-up in the Tick Tock Box short story competition, not Anton Rogers as we had it.'' — ''The Guardian''.

definitions.text: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To depict as being.

quotations.text: We haven't eaten dinner yet, have we?
Your wife hasn't been reading that nonsense, has she?
(UK usage) ''He has some money, hasn't he?

definitions.text: Used as interrogative auxiliary verb with a following pronoun to form tag questions. (For further discussion, see "Usage notes" below)

quotations.text: I could have him!
I'm gonna have you!

definitions.text: (British, slang) To defeat in a fight; take.

quotations.text: I have no German''.

definitions.text: (Irish) To be able to speak a language.

quotations.text: Dan certainly has arms today, probably from scraping paint off four columns the day before.

definitions.text: To feel or be (especially painfully) aware of.

quotations.text: He had a cold last week.
We had a hard year last year, with the locust swarms and all that.

definitions.text: To be afflicted with, to suffer from, to experience something negative

quotations.text: You had me alright! I never would have thought that was just a joke.
"You're a very naughty boy. If I've told you once, I've told you a thousand times. I won't have you chasing the geese!"
